content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
OverviewThe Escapists is a game about escaping prison. You play as one of the prisoners in a variety of different prisons. Despite its initial appearance, the game has an extreme level of depth and even the prison listed as Very Easy (Center Perks) is hard enough that I have yet to escape.Speaking of escaping, there are many methods of doing so, but almost anything you do can be traced back to you by the guards. You can steal plastic knives from the cafeteria and cut the vent open in your cell - but they'll trace it to you. You can climb onto the roof - but you'll get sniped by the guards in the towers. You can dig a tunnel towards the outer fence - but you might leave dirt lying around and the warden will have the hole caved in.You can perform favors for other prisoners to get money, which can be used to buy things from other prisoners. Favors might involve beating down another inmate or taking an item. Many items are illegal (red name) and you will be sent to solitary confinement if you are found with one or one is found in your desk during a cell search.Life in The Escapists is all about keeping the guards off of you, and to do that, you must follow prison routine. In the morning is roll call - you must attend this or the entire prison will be put into lockdown. You also have a job that you must do. The following is the routine on the first prison, Center Perks: Morning Roll Call Breakfast Free Time  Lunch Work, or Leisure if unemployed Exercise Showers Evening Meal Evening Free Time Evening Roll Call Lights OutYou also have skills that can be used. Speed determines your attack speed, strength your attack damage, and intellect is your crafting smarts. You find crafting recipes through notes you can buy (or steal from others), and these stats can be raised in different ways but degrade over time.But this review is getting long, and I don't want to explain every aspect of this game, so let me list off some pros and cons.Pros Very in-depth; great variety of items Large variety; many ways to escape Flavorful; lots of chatting and makes the prison seem real Complete feeling; feels like a full game even in early accessCons Buggy; sometimes there are bugs, like guards shouting at you to get to work while you are at work or people you can't interact with whatsover, i.e. infirmary staff or the warden Solitary; if something is traced to you, you go into solitary regardless of current position or state - basically instant, with no opportunity to escape it Unclear; the game only has a vague tutorial and you must learn on your own, which CAN be funLet me tell you a story.I was a prisoner at the first prison. During the first three days, I made quite a hideout. I made paper mache out of toilet paper and super glue, which I made a fake vent cover out of so I could freely climb up and down the vents without fear of leaving it open. I had a massive storage of illegal supplies, a bludgeoning weapon made out of a sock with soap inside of it, and an outfit with metal plates beneath the cloth. Most of the inmates liked me, and I constantly went around bruising people for pay/One night, I decided to explore the vents more. I left a dummy made with pillows under the covers of my bed to fool the guards into thinking I was asleep. WIth some floss, I cut through slats in the system and saw a stash on the other side of a vent which I could not bypass. I figured I could cut through the vent and go across.Wrong.I fell into the infirmary office. The door was locked, and I hadn't had the foresight to make a key from a mold. In other words, I was trapped, and the infirmary staff always lock the door when they came in. I searched all night for a way through the vent, started chipping through the walls with a screwdriver (which broke), and as the sun rose I resigned to my fate and hid in the supply closet. After morning roll call, the prison went on lockdown. As the confused inmates reported to their cells, I received a notice that the military was on their way to the prison.After a minute and a half, I was found and thrown into solitary.Final ScoreVery in-depth, great fun, and feels complete though in early access. However, it has some standing flaws and errors which interfere with gameplay.I rate The Escapists 8/10.June 6, 2015 update: I still recommend this game. There are a few DLCs which I haven't got around to playing (like the Alcatraz DLC) and it's still quite enjoyable. I'm personally burned out on it, though, and it doesn't offer much outside of the same thing over and over for its price. Wait until it's on sale and it's great value - otherwise, I would skip it.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Let's Play The Escapists #01 (Shankton State Pen) - I'm a Murderer 

			Views: 273,994		

			This is my The Escapists Let's Play at Shankton State Pen. The Escapists is a prison PC game. The Escapists Playlist: http://goo.gl/celjzI The Escapists Epis #1: http://goo.gl/2jtEff ● Twitch:...		

After 7 hours playing The Escapists I have to say it's fun and above all addicting! I'm playing with press access. No matter what route you decide to take, a man of the block prisoner or an educate one, your objective is always the same, escape. There's no wandering for 30 years. Don't let the art style fool you, it is light-hearted but it's challenging as heck. Just like in reality you have to carefully make all your moves and stick to the plan. If something fails you're off to the solitaire, items confiscated and your plan ruined. Fortunately you can load saved games.Pros- crafting items, and there's a lot of choices- save games when you return to the cell at the end of the day- you just don't run out of things to do, the game encourages you to keep moving- it's damn challenging- play it your own way- it's damn funny watching all the incidents during the day, prisoners will interact with each otherCons- the music is repetitive, I had to turn it off and pick my playlist- no customization, I would like to customize my character other than the name

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ah, The Escapists. Such a great game. Where do I start? Let's just do the old pro's and con's.Pros: +AMAZING gameplay. "Simple" objective (escape the prison) and there are sidequests that you can do for your fellow prisoners. +Character Deveopment.Ok, this might sound weird, but this game actually has its own way of a character development. Let's say that you do some sidequests and give away items or cash, then the prisoner(s) that you gave away items to or did sidequests for will have a better opinion on you. That's actually very important. If the prisoners rate you a good opinion (50+), then they will never attack you, give you more money for quests, and give you information when talked to. If the player recieves a bad opinion, then the prisoners that view you that way will attack you, say really useless or mean stuff to you, and give you less money for sidequests. Wait, one more thing, you can buy things from prisoners, and if they like you, then you get a discount. If not, more money. Also, there are 3 skills that your character can learn. Intellect, strength, and speed. Intellect allows you to become more smart at get higher paying jobs. Strength determines how much damage you can take before passing out, and how much damage you can deal. Speed is, well, how fast you can move. (striker311111)+Realism...kindaThis game for the most part is somewhat realistic. You're in a prison, and you have to escape. You scout around the prison and see what there is to be seen. However, time goes by really quickly (one hour in the game feels like 1 or 2 minutes). Oh yeah, and you can get money in prison. How neat is that?+Different prisonsThere are different prisons, each one being more easy or more difficult  than the others. I'm telling you, after you beat the easiest prison, you go to another one, it's gonna be really really difficult. The two problems is that the easiest prison gives a bad impression to the future ones, and that the harder ones are impossible if you DON'T use a guide. (There you go SweetJesus)Cons:-NavigationSince you're in a prison, this should be pretty obvious, but still. I have to warn you, you get so little time to move around and explore, that this game is a ton harder than it should be. You try to escape, but you see a guard in a place that you never knew about and then you get sniped and lose all of your stuff. I know it's realistic, but the player should be able to explore more of the prison.-ItemsNow, I'm only talking about hard to get items. You somehow manage to knock out a guard, and steal his key. You better escape within a short amount of time, 'cause he's gonna wake up soon and you'll get taken in again. Now, there are different keys. Each one opening a specific amount of doors. And you have no idea how to get the keys, so those items that you see in the isolated hallway is gonna be impossible to get to, and that weird room with the generator is a no-no.-TimeOne hour in this game literaly feels like a minute. I know you're not supposed to play a game for 12 hours straight, but it all feels so fast. So much you have to do in so little time, that I think it's a little stressful and intense for players who are new to this game. -The first prison (easiest)Ok, this is kind of a weird con. But I think it's appropriate that I place this here. The very first prison, the easiest one, gives a terrible impression on how future prisons will be. You do all of this work to escape, only to figure out it's really really easy. You expect the next one to be slightly harder, but no. The next prison after that is very, very hard. I still have a lot of trouble to escape it. The first prison should give the player more of a challenge. All you really gotta do is lure a guard near a door, knock him out, steal his key and go. The next prison, I didn't even know how to escape it for a long while.Overall, this is a pretty neat game. Not bad at all, only I would recommend looking up a beginners guide first to get an idea of things rather than just charging in. I rate this game a 7/10. The replay value is amazing, the concept is really nice, but there are some things that could make this game a little better. I hope this review helps.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												I don't have much time in but I’m writing because my initial reaction was so strong.  I'll say first that I've done two years behind bars in the U.S. and almost four in a community corrections facility.  This game immediately started a mild and pleasant sympathetic nervous response (i.e. fight or flight/adrenaline/epinephrine) because of the very simplified, yet somewhat accurate representation of incarcerated life, with its rigorous, paramilitary lifestyle.  I was immediately reminded of the intense cleaning rituals, endless card games, terrible smells, awful food, and the overall lack of privacy and respect from guards and other inmates.  In light of all this, my first successful escape was EXILARATING AS HELL!  This game will appeal to squares and ex-cons a like!9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Escapists is a game by Mouldy Toof Studios. It puts you in one of numerous prisons with the simple goal of escaping. But it isn’t as easy as you think, the point of a prison is to keep you in your place, which is what this game does.You get the choice of one of numerous characters who you can rename, a prison, and the option to name your prisoners if you had a friend you wanted to be with during your life sentence. When it comes to content the game is incredible, there are many different items you can get hold of from soap to post cards. That’s not even all, you can combine items to make more stuff to help you escape; paper mache for fake walls, nunchucks for attacking, key molds, Dummies, glass shanks, fake grates, posters, grappling hooks and so much more!This game requires lots of planning, you can’t just beat up a guard, take his keys and leave. You need to spend some time exercising to get strong, you need key molds to keep keys or else you get time in solitary, there are guard patrols everywhere and even clogging the toilet with dirt from the hole you’ve been digging. You need to plan how you’re going to escape and balance you actual escape attempt with the prison timetable; eating, sleeping, free time, work and roll call. If you don’t fill your work’s quota then you get fired, complete the quota though and you get money to bribe other prisoners or buy stuff from them.The actual gameplay itself is really well done, everything is quite solid and the game is most definitely playable. You can choose from many ways to escape, through the vents, underground, through the front door or even starting a riot. The graphics is designed to look 8-bit, a nice look for many games that is also fairly easy to make. The audio in the game is very well made, and if you like the music playing in the background you can get the music from the game’s steam folder.If you enjoy playing games that require work and planning for you to play and succeed then this is the game for you. I rate this 10/10 in its current Early Access state, it’s a solid game worth the cost to buy it. When it leaves Early Access I don’t think there’s a rating system high enough to grade it… or at least that’s what I think will happen when it leaves Early Access anyway.

								What more can you want (Except later updates)?Escape from prison, in the most strange and familiar ways possible, from digging out with a spoon to beating up all the guards and been allowed to WALK out the prison, helped by the warden.This game has an incredible range of difficulty:If you want to escape a prison, then probably return because they have free food, nice guards (Bodyguards almost) and deluxe toliet paper, choose Center Perks.If you want to (Fail at) escape(ing) prison because they have inmates tougher than the guards (and thats saying something), A personal army armed with stunsticks that knock alomost ANYTHING out with one hit, A small sea and shaving cream then choose HMP Irongate.Also have glitches and a guard heat that is sometimes very funny:If you want to get shot in the balls get to breakfast late that one to many times.If you want to knock out a guard with zero retaliation, do it with a pillow on a certain map (Im not saying which, Bug exploit)Amazing inmate (And own) comments:If you want to ask another inmate whether he made friends in the shower room, do it there.If you want to swear while tring to be sneaky, break a tool while trying to escape steathly (no-one will hear you scream F-)Weapons that are really awesome.If you want to wield nunchucks, two timber and a wireIf you want to nearly kill people with soap, put it in a sockIf you want to make a weapon out of just a comb, hit it agaisnt a wallIn short, If you want to have fun, GET THIS GAME!666 out of 21

Early Access Review
								This game... I saw it on Steam just a few days after it'd come out for Early Access (20th of August) and I thought it looked really cool. I bought it and wow... My brain just exploded with delight.If you've ever played Prison Architect, like me, you'll sorta understand how to play this game. But of course you're not building the prison this time, you're ESCAPING IT. It has a lot of cool mechanics already implemented into it. I won't give you any hints on escaping except you can use screwdrivers on vents.You can even take your clothes off...Guards beat you up for it...But there are a few bugs:I know I have a bad computer, but this is a Pixelated-Art-Style-Kind-Of-Thing game. Framerate is a bit of an issue for me.The guard AI can be a bit annoying aswell. Only a bit. Sometimes, when doing Morning Rollcalls, they'll have a lockdown because I didn't get there within five seconds. Then I have all my illegal items taken ;-;All in all, this game is worth it. DayZ has bugs, but everyone loves it. Minecraft has bugs, but it has grown to be one of the most "Let's Play"ed games out there. I really think if you like the idea of this game and it's style, you should get it.Its price will go up later too. Do you really want that regret?

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Escapists throws you in the deep end of a 16-bit prison with one task. Escape. Easy huh? No. Not even close to easy. I have had so far 13 hours of gameplay and have not yet come even close to having the beggings of an escape plan.... And I'm on the very "easy" map. Though extreemly chalenging it is a extreemly fun and addicting game, you have to follow the daily prison routine. 1. Morning rollcall. 2. Breakfast. 3. Morning free time. 4. Work. 5. Workout. 6. Showers. 7. Lunch. 8. Evening free time. 9. Evening rollcall. 10. Lights out. While sticking to this routine you must find the time to gather recorses, Make friends, make tools, defend yourself from guards and other prisoners and put together and make your escape. You can do little jobs for your fellow inmates doing things from finding a pack of mints to shanking a guard. To escape you can climb through vents. Dig under your cell, Even mine through your cell wall with a plastic fork! All in all it is a great game. Though it is early acsess with only 3 or 4 maps trust me.... You will only have just completed the first by the time this game is completed. Best £7 I have ever spent. 10/10 game and I would honestly suggest to anyone. For all you PC gamers check it out on steam. Watch the videos and look at pics. If your up for it buy it! You will really enjoy the game.

Posted: April 19, 2015
												Do I recommend this? YEAH I DO!The Escapists is a game where you are thrown into prison. You must escape the prison, and believe me, that's not easy.Now, I'm going to be honest and give my pros and cons:~Updated Review~Pros:- Lots of prisons, and cheap extra prison DLC.- Devs listen to us (community)- Amazing art style.- Challenging, you have to be smart to escape, as it isn't easy.- Lots of items and tons of item combos.- Lots of favorites for inmates.- Map editor + submission to workshop.- A semi-realistic prison feel.- Soundtrack is great! There are new songs during free periods.- Inmates speeches are pretty funny. (personal pro for me)- Multiple ways to escape. (Ex: first prison has about 3 (+) ways to escape!)- Custom inmate names, and choosable skins.Cons:- Lots of waiting, and can get very boring if you're not patient.- Cops / guards catch you easily. This makes a challenge, though!- Gets repetitive once in a while, but DLC makes up for it.-So, if you like prison games and have a lot of patience, then this is for you. My old review can be seen below, and I decided to update it as the game has updated a lot since then.Final Score: 8.5/10~Old Review~Pros:- Great art style. (32 bit?)- Soundtrack is great. Every prison has their own free time song that plays.- Challenging.- Tons of items.- Multiple, and I mean multiple escape routes. The first prison has over 3 escape routes!- Favors are really easy to do.- Inmates' speeches are pretty darn funny.- Developers actually listen to us (the community)- Each prison offers new items and layouts, and gets tougher each time.- Map Editor!- Has a realistic prison theme.Cons:- None, go buy the game! (If you haven't.)That's my short review.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Hey, i've had this game for about a month now, so i thought i would share my opinions and experiences with you.  So when i first saw this game i was thinking "Oh wow this is kinda neat, i might get it" so i looked up some gameplay videos to see how good it would be, and i was blown away, now i reccomend you watch Lets Play's and other gameplay videos if you get this because if you don't, you won't escape the first prison, there are so many things to keep in check and so many things to do, i just highly reccomend it, so now on to the review portion...Gameplay - The gameplay is very fun, for those of you who need to know specificly what the game is, its basically a prison escape sim, your set down in a prison, you have to scout out where to escape and how, get the tools for it, get the stats (Strength, intellect and Speed) and wait for the moment to strike, now to be more specific, in order to escape there are three main way you have to use in order to escape (Most of the time) you go low (Digging) you go high (roof tops) and right through the center (Breaking walls and cutting fences) so for example with digging, you can use easily broken plastic spoons from the canteen, a trowel you find on fellow inmates, or a shovel you made, if the guards see the tunnel the trace it back to you and get your stuff taken away, so cover it up, and you also need wooden braces to keep the tunnel from collapsing, now the center, in order to get through the walls you need 3 types of items, a plastic easily broken fork from the canteen, a crowbar, or a pickaxe, once again if the guards see a broken wall they WILL catch you and take away your stuff so you have to make a fake wall block, or get a poster to cover it, and finally the roof, to get to the roof you need to get to a ladder and to get to a ladder you need to break a wall, so in the roof you need rope to get to every where, if the snipers see you on the roof they shoot you, if they see you on the roof with a guard outfit, you have limited time to do your stuff before they recognise your not a guard, but if its night the snipers are gone. Overall i rate the gameplay a 9.5/10Music - The music is very well composed 8-bit style music, not much to be said, overall its an 8/10Programming Bugs - Theres just about no glitches in this game, overall i found about... four? and none game breaking, permanent or effecting gameplay. i rate it a 10/10Community - Now every great game isnt what it is without a community pointing out bugs and what it should have in it, and this community is full of smart innovative people, thanks to them we can have a prison editor and multiplayer some time in the future, they also love to point out bugs and glitches. i rate it a 10/10Final Thoughts - When i got this game i just couldnt stop playing it, the overall score is 9.25/10

												Awesome game!I play this game all the time (still stuck on Shankton State Pen though D:<) and I'm amazed by the amount of mechanics and  items in the game! When I first saw the game, I glossed over it as "just another prison escape game." Then I learned about jobs, storing items in a vent, prison takeovers, wrapping people in a rope so you can steal their job, and things like that!I think something that should be added is more abilities for NPCs. As of now, if an NPC has contraband in their desk, and they are called for a cell search, nothing happens. Something else I would love to see added is multiplayer, perhaps you could make a local game where two people can try to escape a prison, or there can be minigames which players from around the world can play!All in all, this is a very fun game and I think you should play it!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												The idea is solid. maintain your prison life while secretly plotting your escape. The problem falls on the mechanics. Stats and relationships fall extremely fast. The tutorial tells you almost nothing of value. Crafting unlocks are hard to come by making the game frustrating without a wiki or tutoial. The worst offender, though, is the guard AI. They apparently hire all guards from the psychic network. Guard finds random thing in random place: blam you're caught. Guard is walking by a dark room at night and instantly notices the vent is open: blam caught. Guard goes to check your room that has a hole covered and all contraband smuggled out: he decides to look behind the poster, blam again. You've been crawling through the vents you wait until things are clear climb down: blam guard come speeding down the hallway befor you can react. And, of course if you are caught, they know instantly where everything you've set up is and undo it.I want to like this game, but it feels more like a chore than fun. There is some charm and some entertaining things that can happen, but there is little pay-off to what you put in.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Chipping trough walls with plastic forks. Crafting make-shift weapons. Scouting out the prison. Getting the right items. Dodging guards. Living prison life. Getting keymolds. Getting better jobs. Leveling stats. Getting a guard outfit. Covering up dug holes and chipped walls. Finnaly getting out to the perimiter wall. Get shot by a guard in a tower, taking all your items and putting you into solitary. Trying again. Succes. Reliazie this was the easiest prison, and a even harder one awaits you.Sounds like fun? It is fun.Pros:- 6 defualt prisons, along side 2 custom. (3 if you had early acces)- A sea of non-craftable and craftable items.- A easy to understand crafting system.- A helpfull and lovely community.- Amazing soundtrack.- The abillity to name all guards and in-mates.- 9001 ways to escape the prison.- Very polished and alsmost bug free.-PRISON EDITORCons:- Very rage inducing.So all in all, The Escapist is an amazing game and should be played at all costs. Fun and compelling, challenging and extrmely high quality. Easy to get into, hard to master. Well, I am off to see if my plan works this time.10/10

Early Access Review
								I am just going to keep this short, for i have only logged around 4 hours into the game as of now, but as soon as i reach around 10 hours i will write a full review.So, i was browsing youtube one night when i noticed a video on some new indie game "The Escapists." Noticing instantly that this was some sort of prison simulator, of which i am very fond of, i clicked it and instantly loved it. Not having any money at the time i desperatly searched for ways to get this game for the following days, finally while looking through my inventory i noticed a $ 10 CSGO weapon skin and proceded to sell it without hesitation. I purchased the game and quickly downloaded it (Very quickly) and began to play. I was hooked. It was something i had wanted for a while but could never find, a prison escape simulator, where all the knowledge i had mustered from watching prison movies came in handy. Shortly after starting i grabbed some plastic spoons and started digging, i hung some sheets over the cell bars to stay concealed, and within a few nights, i had been sent to solitary when the guards discovered my uncovered hole.So.I started again.After an hour of seemingly doing the same thing again and again i still wasn't bored and found new features at every turn.I love the pixelated graphics, the game gives off a light vibe but it is very hard.Also the new POW camp prison is awesome and i have put 3 hours into it already.With the constant updates and the way the devs listen to our ideas this game is definatly worth the money.I won't give it a rating yet but this game certainly has my attention.

content:
Posted: January 9
												I nearly didn't get this game just because of the graphics, but I'm so glad I did in the end. Despite it's simplistic RPG maker looking surface it's actually a very deep gameIn The Escapists you go from prison to prison attempting to escape which unlocks the next prison in succession. There are 6 prisons in total which vary in style and increase in difficultyGameplay involves a strict schedule of showing up for rollcall (a sort of headcount to make sure no one has escaped) followed by breakfasts, work routines, exercise period, shower period, an evening meal and an evening rollcall followed by returning to your cell for lights out, with usually 2 free periods available inbetween. Later prisons have an afternoon rollcall as wellWhile going through the routine of prison life you need to devise an escape plan. Early ones are simple as there's usually only something like a locked door and a wire fence inbetween you and freedom, a couple of forged keys and a pair of wirecutters will take care of that, and most early prisons can simply be tunnelled out of if you find a good place to begin the tunnel. However the number of obstacles gradually increases with fences being electrified but linked to a generator, additional locked doors, security cameras, contraband (metal) detectors, landmines, patrol trucks, and underground electric fences or walls that cant be broken through to prevent tunnel escapes, it'll be up to you to find the weak spots in these defences. There are usually multiple solutions for each prison thoughThe game has a stat system sort of like The Sims. Intelligence unlocks crafting options, speed increases attack speed (DPS) and strength increases HP (tankiness). You can also recruit prisoners who you befriend in order to fight guards and create distractionsIn order to carry out these things there is an extensive crafting system. While you can use simple items like plastic cutlery, nail files and trowels, you will need to use crafting to acquire more effective and specialised tools, which are tied to an intelligence stat. For example you can craft together a crowbar, duct tape and a tool handle made of wood and a file to create a simple pickaxe and use it to break through walls, or do the same but with a piece of sheet metal instead of a crowbar to make a shovel for digging. Whereas you can knock out a guard or order a gang of inmates to knock him out in order to steal his uniform, you could also craft one by bleaching a prison inmate outfit and dying it with ink. Guards will react to holes in the wall but a roll of duct tape and a magazine can be used to make a pinup poster to cover the hole. If you maintain good relations with the guards they will let you hang up sheets over your cell, allowing you to dig a hole and cover it with your desk whenever you aren't working on it if you want to. Or you could remove the vent cover from your cell with a screwdriver and replace it with a paper mache replica that enables you to stash things in the vents or maneuver through the prison at nightIf a guard sees a hole, spots a hole in the wall or finds illegal contraband in your desk you'll be sent to solitary confinement for a few days, the prison will be searched thoroughly and all your stashed contraband will be found and any holes you made in the floor and walls will be filled so it's important to hide your escape plans as you progressAs if that weren't enough, the developers have produced several DLC maps, some of which must be purchases but others like the christmas inspired prisons "santa's sweatshop" and "jingle cells" are completely free and produced for us by the dev team!There is also a prison creator system and a lot of custom prisons also available to download for freeThe Escapists is not an easy game, and the path to escape isn't always clear. It takes good problem solving skills and an understanding of the game mechanics to progress or you'll never even escape the first prison. If you're looking for a challenge then you'll find it in the escapists

number of helpful: 82 of 114 people (72%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Key supplied by developer for review.======================================The Escapists Read on for full review!======================================TL;DR:BUY IT. Great tutorial, good music, fun and extremely immersive gameplay.Accessible as heck, but with depth.======================================Pros+UI: Great layout, simple, intuitive.+Graphics: Who doesn't love some nice pixel art? Great light/shade/colors.+Sound: A bit chunky, but good, retro, immersive.+Gameplay: One of the most immersive games I've playedCons-None so far!Neutral+/- Settings: Only so many, and sliders can't be dragged! Nbd for me.======================================So The Escapists is essentially a time management/prison lifestyle sim. This game is a delight! The graphics are very good, and serve their purpose well. Areas are distinct, everything has light, shadow, and a suitable color. The pixel art is very well done. The sprites are cute, and some of them realistic for their size. Also, every object is distinct. The UI is 100% serviceable, with distinct colors and objects of its own, and just the right amount of polish.The tutorial, also, is amazing. It's quick, easy, and gives you a nice step by step introduction to the world with a step by step instructionset, without spoiling the deeper elements to the game such as crafting recipes. The gameplay is equally as accessible, everything being a simple tap, right click, or left click away...and maybe a few alternating keys. You can customize the controls, but I'm not sure why you'd ever need to! It makes me think of the Sims, except you are playing the character, and you choose what to do. There is an ASTONISHING amount of freedom in gameplay. You can blend in, you can sneak off, you can build your stats, or trade contraband with the inmates. Start fights. Steal. Do favors, or EVEN your job! The list goes on!! But your primary goal is of course to escape, and on that note, the AI is responsive, so you better be ready. I've encountered no bugs so far.The music is serviceable, and that's about it. It isn't intrusive, it isn't bad, but it isn't amazing. It works for the setting and I definitely like it, but I don't completely love it. The sound effects are basic and perhaps slightly jarring at times.The only issues I've had with the game are the lack of resolution settings, and some desks not wanting to leave my arms easily. The RNG can create some unforgiving wait times, but it also makes things a bit intense and there's a lot of anticipation. This game has actually made me feel anxious, and gotten my heart beating at times! There are all kind of custom maps the community has made, which can offer a unique flavor or new twist or challenge, which is nice. On a related final note, the difficulty is present, with the game leaving it up to you how you want to escape, as well as how to do some of the things required to do just that, but once you figure it out, the prisons difficulty scales quite nicely.All in all, I've never so quickly felt so at home in a game.Now if only I could find that dental floss... ;)======================================If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

number of helpful: 35 of 39 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off you DO NOT NEED A PROCCESSOR EQUIVLANT TO THE RECOMMENDED. I have a dual core cpu that runs at 1.65 Ghz no where near the recomended 2.4 Ghz and it runs flawless for me. This game could probably be ran on a a single core processor.      If you like building prisons in the amazing Prison Architecht you will love this  game! It might look like a childish/retro 8-bit game, but think again. In this game you are forced to use your brain to the brink of it's processing power. Along with escaping you have to make it to roll call's 3 times a day, eat 3 times a day, exercise 1 time a day, shower 2 times a day, and work once a day if you have a job. If you do not manage your time wisely and are able to keep with the schedule you will not escape.      There are more ways to escape then I can count. You can dig, use the vents and roof, cut through fences, break through walls, steal keys and more. You usually have to use multiple different things out of those to be able to espcape.  There are tons of items also that you can craft to help you escape. Along with these items you can only craft them if you have a high enough intellect and in order to get and keep it up you have to work out your mind each day.      You have to be super sneaky or the guards will catch you off guard and throw you into solitary. If you get thrown into solitary they will search all your stuff and take any contraband and you will have to start over which at times comletely screws you up and can be esier to start over.       This game is full of stuff to do and has hours upon hours of gameplay and it's only in early access! I just barely escaped for the first time! It took me 15 hours! This game is complex and amazingly hard which gives it that super fun experience and the amazing feeling of accomplishment when you finaly escape!     I reccomend this game to anyone and say it is 100% worth the price! To all of you reading this, BUY THIS GAME!!!

number of helpful: 112 of 165 people (68%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												I want to like this game. I really do. And it isn't really a "bad" game. It just has too many issues for me to reccomend it. If there were a "meh" option I'd pick it. I have two major issues with the game.One being you aren't given a lot of important information. Metal Detectors can find everything on you that you DON'T wear. You can have nunchuks and a metal plated uniform and it won't detect it. But if you have a nail file in your pocket you instantly go to solitary. Lots of weird recipes where you might have an idea of something CLOSE to what you can do, or maybe you have part of the items you need, but you won't ever know unless you get luck finding the recipe note. And two, RNG is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I spent roughly 4 days in the 2nd prison with three key moulds. I had gotten nunchuks and made metal plated prisoner armor. I had accumulated a bit over 150 dollars and I spent four whole days just stuck. I needed to make a key to progress, and I was missing a lighter. I searched EVERY inmate's desk multiple times every day. I checked every inmate store. This continued on and on. Eventually I just pulled a chuck norris and attempted to beat down all the guards. Which did barely work. But felt very unsatisfying.I don't mind slow progression as long as I can make actual progression. But when I'm stuck sitting doing nothing for days in game because I am not getting an item I need the enjoyment just becomes massive frustration.There's also some kind of irritating small things, like how if a vent if missing from the roof of your room a guard will INSTANTLY notice if he walks by. I'm not sure how many guards stare at ceilings, but it seems a bit silly. Not to mention you can't seem to frame other inmates which is VERY disappointing. It's basically flavor text. You can be told they are about to search the room of so and so, and throw a glass shiv in his desk, but the guards will not give a♥♥♥♥♥♥ They only throw you into solitary.  The game has a lot of great ideas and is close to what I want, but there are some serious underlying flaws in the game. I'm not sure I'll come back, very disappointing.

number of helpful: 26 of 28 people (93%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Like some mind-bending combination of MYST and every classic top-down RPG in history, the Escapists manages to blend heart pounding moments of adrenaline and reaction, with cerebral activities, in a well paced fashion. Long and careful hours of scheming, conniving, poisoning, sabotaging, exploring, manipulating, and chipping away (literally) at your confinement, sit side by side with vicious scrums and scraps.What makes this game so amazing is that it gives you the chance to live out that mental fantasy where you imagine that you could do a better job of breaking out of jail than any number of TV or Movie characters (or even real-life felons).  Ironically for a game about being imprisoned, this game provides true freedom;  Freedom to piece together your own unique plan of escape.The game is quite robust in terms of replayability, very stable (no crashes or bugs so far in my playthroughs), and requires very little by way of system resources.  It will, however, tax your brain, your wit, and your reflexes, in the best way.

number of helpful: 50 of 69 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												This game hits so many marks, but drops the ball in big ways that make it ultimately unfun and punishing in unfulling ways. This game has an awesome concept and has a ton of freedom in actually pulling off your daring escape,  but the problem comes from it's very unfair, unforgiving difficulty and grind-heavy RNG loot system. I don't regret getting it, but at the price their asking, this game just isn't worth it. In fact, it's only worth it for those who are curious about what a good prison escape game could look like, since there really isn't anything else like it. The biggest bone to pick is the difficulty. If a guard walks in on your doing anything uncouth, you're caught, your tools of escape are taken and thrown into the void and you're basically left to start from scratch with just about all progress lost. Now this wouldn't actually be a huge problem if the guards played by the rules. There's a lack of a more refined in-game logic. Every punishment is sweeping and is basically a soft "Game Over," leaving you with 90% of you progress lost. WHERE you get caught or what you did to get caught do not factor into what the guards take from you. If you've been stashing goods in the vents for the past hour and you get busted digging a hole, everything you have in the vents is taken, even though you were caught underground. Anecdotally, I had stashed a ton of escape tools in the vents and decided to beat up a guard and see if I could steal his key. I pulled it off, but you have exactly 20-30 seconds before you receive a note saying they know you took the key and you're busted -- a.k.a. soft "Game Over." I can accept getting busted for taking a key after pummelling a guard. The problem is, after taking the key, I ran and stashed it in another inmate's desk along with my other tools, knowing full well I'd be busted in mere moments. The message popped, I went to solitary confinement for three days, then was loosed to get back to my master plan. I ran back to the inmate's desk to find that the key was missing, but my other illegal tools were still there. Furthermore, I went to check the vents and for whatever reason, they had taken everything out of them and replaced the fake vent cover I placed. The checked the vents because I stole a key? And they magically found the key, but didn't take the other tools I placed in the other inmate's desk? Doesn't make a whole lot of sense, and that's one of the big places the game fails: it just throws a blanket punishment instead of one that makes sense for the situation.The other major problem is RNG. You'll need specific items for every escape method you can conceive; not just one, but several of them to craft and for each individual step of your escape. But the game is so incredibly stingy about giving you any items you need that your best bet is to plot several different escape methods at the same time, just using tools and items as they pop up. This kind of detracts from the idea of planning your escape, since you're never really given any sort of choice or method to obtain key items necessary for escape, and with an incredibly limited inventory space, no place to truly protect your items, and a guarantee of losing near everything you've accumulated if you get busted for any single misdeed, it can take an hour just to prepare a single escape attempt, not even properly execute it.It's such a shame, because the freedom the game allows for is like something out of the early days of PC games, but this freedom means very little when you are bound to RNG for all of your tools and you can lose all of those tools in a literal second of wrongdoing -- an hour of work gone in a second. I would expect a game like this to be harsh but fair. Instead, we have a game that's just harsh and becomes a tedious grind after a few hours of play.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												The idea is great, but the game gets so annoying because of instabusts.You just took over the prison and the warden said you made your point and you're free to go? Well, hopefully nobody finds contraband in your desk now, because if they do it's a one-way-ticket to solitary without you being able to do anything against that. You get a message and bam. Try again. Stole a key from a guard? Oh yeah. As soon as they wake up they know it was you and they also instantly know where you are. To the solitary!I also just dug a tunnel. Over 50 tiles. Took me more than 3 ingame weeks and required♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of duct tape. My only problem was the electrical fence. So I dug to the generator room. counted tiles. I wait for the night, want to dig up to shut down the generator. But nope: As soon as my hole is open I get a message that a tower guard spotted it and that I have to go to solitary. Yeah. Thanks. Do they have X-Ray vision and are able to look into ♥♥♥♥ing buildings?Stuff like this really ruins the game, as it really restricts you in what you can do and it doesn't even make any sense the way they did that. Why not let the guards order a shakedown when they notice a key is missing? Search every cell and prisoner. This would at least give you some time to maybe frame another prisoner for stealing it or give you the last few seconds you need to escape. And it would be more realistic and less annoying. The way it is it feels more like an adventure with the solution predetermined by the developers. If I want to dig a 100 tile tunnel to escape you should at least honor that I did that instead of throwing me into solitary with a ♥♥♥♥ing message.

number of helpful: 24 of 27 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Escapists is a brilliant little title that is well worth the money even in it's early access stage.The aim of the game is simple, you must escape from your prison but it's not as simple as just waiting til the guards backs are turned and making a wild dash for it. You start in a prison with various other inmates and are told the basics (WASD to move, right click to interact, left click to use) and from then on out, you're on your own. Each day has a schedule which you will need to follow including rollcalls, mealtimes, worktime and freetime in order to keep the guards off your back. Whilst following the daily schedules you have the ability to do favours for other inmates earning money and boosting their opinion of you, workout or read to increase your skills (making you a more proficient fighter or able to apply for better jobs and craft better items), or plan your escape. You can choose to keep a low profile and gather the items you need for your escape or you can beat the crap out of everyone who looks at you funny and spend half your game in the infirmary, The game already has a variety of features such as crafting, basic skill building, various jobs, legal and contraband items, fatigue levels and 'friendship' levels with other inmates. There seems to be various different way to escape and in the 4 hours i've played i've not been bored once which is always a good sign for an Early Access game. I think the game is worth the small price tag, and even if you don't plan on buying it yet, 100% keep your eye on it, its truly a game with great potential.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												The Escapists is a very well done prison-break simulator. The many different items you can acquire(or steal)allow you to escape in your own way. The increasingly difficult prisons will make sure you always have a challenge(even the "easy" prison will give you a hard time if not done correctly). And with a built-in map editor, you can create your own prisons, and share them on the Steam Workshop. You can also download other people's prisons to play at any time, so that you never run out of prisons to play. If you have $20 laying around, this is a great time-killer, and an uncommonly challenging, and engaging game

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												the escapists is hard! trying to figure out what to do and how to escape is difficult i have some problems with it one being that guards seem impossible to beat compared to you and at the moment there is little to no tutorial (which i assume will change) the hardest part is figuring out what crafts together altough they have a system (i think this is right anyway) that red named items can't be crafted [edit loutheman13 has informed me red=ilegal items and can be crafted]. crafting guides are hard to come buy and what ive seen pretty bad as require already crafted materials that you won't know how to make. But overall it is tense and so far i havn't figured out a way to escape and you can in see my time above (i will edit when i have beat and at what time) i havn't been able to leave the easiest prison which is the only one but i expect will add more as they have said so in the description. so far this game is exactly what i have expected of it and so far ive loved every second! edit: they have now added a 4th job within the first couple of weeks which i hope is a sign of the devs reliability to continue the escapists so i can enjoy this game further.edit: More prisons have been added aswell as a tab for custom prisons (steam workshop lets hope) meaning the replayability has just sky rocketed. *Tiny spoilers* Some things seem to be a bit harsh for example i filed a vent out in someone elses cell and it was unnoticed for 3 days then radomly it was noticed, linked to me i was in solitary and all contraband was taken away, i also dislike how you are instantly caught if you are in a vent or underground so there is no way avoid it (i would like to think this is just because certain elements havn't yet been added like guards underground or in vents). still believe it's worth the money and a written tutorial (instructions) have been added and i still havn't escaped. (i probably suck). Hope this helped.edit 2: This game has some real issues and if i could id change my review to a side thumb. I mean its repetitive but im ok with that, the things that annoy me are the little things and they have made me uninstall the game. For example my biggest pet peeve is that a stolen key will always lock you up, let me give you an example, i recruited 3 guys and told them to beat a guard up around the corner i went around the corner and picked up the key and placed it in somebody elses cell, guard wakes up i get sent to solitary. I mean i could understand a shakedown but no instant arrest. another issue is that other people cant seem to get sent to solitary, beating up guards? no, contraband in cell during shakedown? no, nothing. I enjoy escape mode more in prison architect and am seriously dissapointed with this but i will keep it as recommended for 2 reasons, the devs support is great and that should be rewarded, i think these things are only gonna be only slight issues for others whilst for me there so frustrating i dont wanna play this and the idea of the game is enjoyable.

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												As I had the privilege of meeting Chris Davis this weekend at Insomnia 54 (nice guy!), I thought I'd take the time to leave my thoughts.An awesome prison simulator, with an old-school twist. Hours of fun to be had.Each prison appears to have a well defined strategy, although alternative methods can be carried out (e.g. beating up all of the prison guards, molding gate keys., etc) Different prisons have a different routine to follow and it is vital that you get to know this routine in order to plan your escape successful. For example, a 10am rollcall must be attended to ensure the guards don't get suspicious that you're upto no good. Clearly a lot of thought went into the crafting system. Items can be combined to make new ones that you will need in order to escape from the prison of choice.I completely love the whole 8-bit vibe that The Escapists has going on. Old school graphics and old school sound effects help set the tone very well.The only bug I've personally found in this game is when getting my intellect to 100 by browsing the internet at the computer in the first prison, the achievement did not unlock for me.  I did get the chance to mention this to Chris, so I'm hoping this will get sorted out soon, if it hasnt been addressed already.All in all, buy this game if you like challenging, stategic thinking and are looking for a game that will keep you engrossed for ages! (Drop the soap.)

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
The Escapist - helping you escape from reality by immersing you into... reality?! Let me explain. The Escapist is an in-depth, yet somewhat simplistic, simulator centered around you, an everyday con, trying to break free from prison. Achieving freedom isn't easy, so get ready to make friends with your fellow prisoners, work, work out, buy, collect and craft... and try at all time to not drop the soap. So, how is jail? There are several main prisons, escalating in difficulty. Each one of them has its own rules you must follow, tight security, number of guards and cameras. They differ in design and prompt you to vary your strategy and plans. Furthermore, you can create your own shutter, so go ahead, build your wall. The Escape. Even when you're not following the prison schedule, you have to be planning out and following your own. Your con has to decide whether to collect some forks and go chip at the wall, or whether to get a spoon and start digging. Will he work out a few extra hours or study at the library. Time is valuable and everything you do matters!  Arts and crafts... and shivs. There are many different items you can find around by rummaging through other cells, or you can just buy them off of other prisoners. Magazines, chocolate, duct tape and lighters all come in handy. Some more advanced items, however, require to be crafted, like weapons, uniforms, keys and tools - this is where studying pays off.  Talking about paying. A valued prisoner, is one who helps out his buddies. Doing favours for other prisoners is a big part of The Escapist. This is how you earn their trust and respect. Plus in return they'll do the digging for ya'. Some cons will want you to find them a specific item, while others'll want you to beat up a foe of theirs. Packing a punch requires working out, so spend a few extra hours at the gym. So where's the simplicity? The Escapist is an indie title, with colourful pixelated graphics and a friendly interface. This fools a lot of people into thinking that the game is simplistic. Underneath the flamboyant cover art lies a manual of a game. Learning all the mechanies will take you some time and your will be prone to looking up guides. Final verdict: So after all the blabbering is The Escapist worth checking out? Absolutely yes! I invested in this game while it was still Early Access and boy did it pay off! Not only will this game entertain you, but it will devour your time, as you're planning along your next big escape. So get it and put your own little twist on The Shawshank Redemption.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Dammit, I bought another game that was in early access and I feel screwed. I bought it after the "Full Release" though, so why do I feel screwed? Because this game does not feel like it should have been moved to "Full Release" yet.Don't get me wrong. I love the idea of it and the degree of freedom it gives in terms of strategies you can come up with. I love the 8-bit semi-goofy guards, inmates, and general prison life. I love the interactions with your peers in crime and the routines of the day that you can end up using to your advantage. I love what they've done with it so far -- and while that is something okay to say about an early access game, it is not okay to say about a Full Release.You see, none of those things feel fully fleshed out. Sure the NPCs have funny dialogue, but by 2-3 in-game days of play, you've heard it all. Oh, someone ate all the cream custards again? Or stole the warden's toupee? Shouldn't he have that glued on by now? And the amount of times your hear about an inmate's wife leaving them or dying is just not possible in a monogamistic society.You can do favors for your fellow inmates but these are a selection of 3 different types of "Quests" with random targets: you're either going to find them an item, distract the guards at a specific time, or beat up someone they don't like. They get pretty repetitive shortly, and sometimes they play out ridiculously -- you beat someone up, notice they have a quest item on them for a quest that they gave you, take it from them, and then give it back to them to complete the quest. Some people think that's quirky and funny but to me it's an incomplete system. Why can I give someone their own pillow and complete a quest for them? And it would be cool to see other quest types, too, like an inmate asking you to plant evidence in another inmate's cell, or have them invite you to their escape attempts or vice-versa.One of the biggest things that seems unfinished are the so-called "Instabusts". When you break a vent, dig a hole, steal a guard's key or do anything else "escapy", even when no guard is in sight or would otherwise know, you are almost intantly discovered unless you do something to cover it up. It makes sense to make a fake vent cover so a guard strolling by later won't notice anything suspicious, but they notice RIGHT AWAY, relying only on their psychic guard powers. They know it was you whether you're breaking a vent in the bathroom or have dug a hole in another inmate's cell, too. Sneakiness is out the window. Plus, the second that they detect you, you're thrown into solitary. They don't start sweeping the cells or climbing into the vents, you're just caught. With a note from the Warden saying "Nice Try", of course.I can practically hear a meeting between the developers where one of them said, "And then we'll have the guards start a search or line up everybody for inspection," but they just never implemented it. It's a game mechanic where something more should happen but doesn't, and it feels incomplete.When you put all these things together, you realize that the game's promise of "Think up your Own Escape Plan" doesn't really let you do all the strategies you may come up with. Want to conspire with other inmates to set up distractions or get supplies for you? Can't. Want to go to a seldom-patrolled part of the prison and climb into the vents? The guards will know anyway. Can you even make a key out of soap, one of the most used prison-break tropes? Nope.Even as I write this, I worry I'm being too hard on this game. It's not like any of these things make it unplayable or broken. It just doesn't feel like a Full Release. In the time I played I kept thinking of mechanics and details that it would be cool for the dev team to add, but it's not in Early Access anymore. The game is even fun to play for a while, and this review is sooooo close to a Recommended. But, in the end, the game doesn't seem to have enough polish to make that fun varied or lasting. They should have finished it first.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game.  The concept is super cool, and the fact that it's basically a puzzle game is very interesting, but the gameplay itself doesn't have any soul.  It too often feels like work.  Very little of what you have to do is intuitive, specifically the crafting and how you are meant to interact with the environment.  Items have no descriptions to indicate their potential functions.  Characters are just pawns to manipulate, you can't really interact with them in a meaningful way to glean info on how the game works, what might be going on in your prison, or what you might be able to do with them (on top of them being personally indistinguishable from one another).  I too often just had to look something up to see if I could do it, and if I could, how, because it was rarely obvious.  For example, I knocked out a guard and immediately tried what I knocked him out for: making a mold of his key using my soap bar.  Nope.  Or how about making the key using the correct mold - molten plastic?  Got a lighter and a plastic fork and - nope.  Plastic has to come from a comb or toothbrush, I discovered when I looked it up.  Alternatively, I could pay my character's money to use the payphone to get randomized hints about what to do, but why can't I just glean this info from playing the game? It is otherwise simply not there.The stats for your character also feel like artificial blockades, and why they degrade I'm not really sure.  I don't want to spend 3 minutes clicking one spot in order to get smarter, or pressing the Q and E keys over and over to get stronger or faster.  It's just not fun, so why have it?  The worst part is you don't level these stats up in any other way besides the exercise task or the reading task, so you are forced to engage in these activities.  Increasing these stats based on what quests you complete would have been a good idea, or based on moving around the prison, but it doesn't work that way - you must exercise or read, which amounts to wasting time both in-game and in real life.  Nothing quantified how I feel about this game better than clicking the bookshelf and watching the "reading" meter fill up over the course of a couple seconds.When the game works, it works very well. Attempting an escape is thrilling and got my pulse going. It's just the process of getting there that is not fun. I don't want to have to have a browser window open when I can't figure out why I can't combine a pillow and a prison outfit to make a bed dummy, or why the entrance key won't let me out of the prison, and for that matter what these colored locks mean and why I have to actually obtain the keys to them before I can even see their names.This game feels like it was designed by people who are very comfortable with having a browser window open in crafting and survival games, as though that's just the accepted reality of these games.  That's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ reality, man.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												This happened to be my first game on steam that was purchased for me by my mate and at this time, i really enjoyed the game after watching many youtubers such as inthelittlewood and jacksepticeye play it. However, its now a year later, and i find myself not returning to this game anytime soon.To start with gameplay, at first it can be really fun, i like the crafting system and the fact you have to find a way to escape each prison by using different items and i have managed to escape 2 of these prisons so far. However whenever i go back to play this game, i just find it very repetitive and boring as i'm just doing the same things every in game day with no real gameplay changes. The game can also get really boring as sometimes you have to wait around for certain things to happen and this unfortunately ruins the game for me. Perhaps im not really into simulation games and i may return to this game someday, but to me, this feels like the type of game that you could just watch someone else play to completion and still feel satisfied. I cannot recommend this game because of these reasons, however if you are into simulation style games, then this game could be for you. The only thing i recommend is that you don't play this game for to long each day as this is the main cause for the game to get boring and repetitive.Overall 5/10 - Good game but very slow to progress. Having only one prison (the easiest) prison unlocked at the beginning leaves no real option in gameplay unless you buy the DLC.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Incredible game. Very light-hearted humor, but it is extremely fun. The necessity to follow your routine to maintain your cover is great, and really adds to the drama of trying to escape. Hiding your tools, using fake walls, looting other prisoners when they get beat up - it's dog eat dog, and I love it. The art style was a good choice, in my opinion. It's pixel art, which works great for this setting. Even with the limited tile size, the game manages to look good, I've never wondered "What is that supposed to be?"The music is very catchy, though the only drawback I have is the transition between 'periods' feels disjointed. Going from, say, free time to lunch, for example, it's very noticeable that it's loading a new background song, as the first one just ends, and the other begins. The gameplay is good. The controls are very tight, and the UI is intuitive. The cursor does a good job of telling you what it's currently doing, in terms of combat, using items, or interaction. Difficulty wise, it's got a bit of a learning curve. But once you kind of learn your routine, you can start picking your times to work on your escape. It's challenging to find the right tools, or enough tools, so you do tend to have to stockpile before you can really get to work. Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												EDIT:  This review is very outdated, and since the addition of the white locked doors, this no longer works.I have created the best strategy at beting this game.  Ever.It took me only 27 minutes to beat it, and I beat it at lunch of Day 3.       The problem is everyone thinks of the most elaborate scheems ever to beat the game (through the vent, digging underground, etc.)  But this plan is simple, and I mean SIMPLE.  All you have to do is collect a few things:1. Tub of talcum powder2. Toothpaste3. Comb/Toothbrush4. Lighter5. Somewhat good weapon      After collecting these things your going to require at least 80 intel so you can craft the tub of talcum powder and toothbrush into a wad of putty,  then use the lighter and comb/toothbrush to make molten plastic.  After doing so get at least 35 health (70 strength), and around 40 speed or so.      Now that you've got all the hard work done, it's time for the fun part.  You're going to beat up gaurds until you have the one with a staff key, if he doesn't have the red staff key, don't take it.  When you find the one with the red staff key take it off him, and combine the key with the wad of putty.  and it is EXTREMELY imortant that after you make the staff key mold you put the real staff key back on him.  If you don't do so you will lose all your items.  Now you have a staff key mold.  craft the staff key mold with the molten plastic So you will get a plastic staff key.  Once you have this you're ready to escape.  All you have to do is when the guards are doing rolecall (So 3 of them are occupied, and 2 are guarding)  You run out the front door,  select the staff key,  click one of the doors with a red lock with you're plastic staff key, and  run out the unlocked door to freedom.      If you've read this far, thanks for taking the time to read this quick guide to win easy, and I hope it helps!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been waiting for this game ever since it came out on greenlight over a year ago, checking each month to see what progress was made. Let me just say that this game was worth the wait. I am a big fan of 'pixel games' and this game is no exception. The game has captured the theme of living in a prison very well, making you want to escape from the dreadful prison!This game very enjoyable as is both fair and difficult. Although it can be a real challenge to escape the prison, the general gameplay is simple and lets you choose how you want to play. With very simple guidlines and controls, you get a hang of the game in a flash. You can either escape through the vents, tunnel underground, obtain fake keys or now, with the new update, beat down all of the guards! The escaping part of the game is the hardest and very intense. This game does currently have only 1 prison to escape from, but I am sure that there will be more prisons in the future as they are frequently updating the game. The most recent update allowed more ways to escape as well as new uniforms to enhance the way you play. The crafting aspect of the game is incredible. With countless things availiable to craft, you can either discover the vast diversity of crafting through crafting notes, or steam guides :). With the developers working on the game at an outstanding pace, there will for sure be way more crafting options, as well as new items, then there are now.Games with good AI are the ones that stand out for me, and this is one of them. The prisoners have their own way of doing things with there personal opinion on you. They may fight you if you have done things that they don't like which have stacked up, or join you in fighting guards if you help them enough. They have challenges for you which you can do for money, in which you can buy vital items you need to escape with. I'm am sure with the new updates that come that these inmates will continue to become more intelligent and my even try to escape from you. Being a Prison Architect fan, the idea of being an actual prisoner inside the game itself was fasinating. This game really pulled it off well, as the gameplay, AI and content all added up to this game being a thriving success. This game will continue to get better and better as the updates continue to improve the game. It deserves more popularity that is has in my opinion. Overall Score 9/10

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												This game is super cool and intense as hell. The learning curve is of an acquired taste, and there's a lot of trial and soul-and-progress-shattering error but it's well worth it and is a better experience for it.Sometimes you'll fail a lot just trying to work out the rules of the game and I can see how some would find that frustrating. But I still generally respect the decision to lean the design in this direction.If you find yourself tempted to look up crafting recipes via Wiki's etc I would advise you to try not doing so, and simply allow yourself to be immersed in this fun little prison life sim and start putting ideas together just as I suppose you really would if you we're planning some kind of daring escape! Try things out and experiment, the recipes and working ideas i've discovered just by putting two and two together were incredibly rewarding, infact so were the recipes that you get out of finding and acquiring "crafting notes". There's an immense sense of satisfaction in finally making your first escape after 28+ days of learning the game inside of the first prison. It feels very real and rewarding and triumphant in a way not many games can offer. Because of how open the game is, the plan you make is your plan and will in some way be probably quite different to everyone elses plan. I got very invested in my first escape when I finally committed to "making a break for it".It's also jusssst accessible and forgiving enough, with _just_ stupid enough AI to make the player feel reasonably comfortable with experimenting and trying out crazy ideas. A very difficult balance to get right.Awesome game.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												When i first got this game, I thought it was pretty fun. But as i played further, the game really lost its charm and became really boring. There are really no fun ways of escaping, and for the most part, escaping is impossible unless you google how to do it. If there was a way to organize an escape with other inmates, this game would be leaps and bounds greater. But of course the other inmates are pretty useless for anything other than items. You always see the same few jokes that have lost their novelty 1 or 2 hours into the game, and talking to them only gets your respect up. That respect doesn't translate into them helping you in fights or building a gang; it only makes their comments change to a happier tone. They don't give you tips on how to escape, you cant task them to do your dirty work... The disconnect between NPC and the player is so frustratingly low. I hate the fact that the game feels less like a prison and more like an endless challenge with no real satisfaction.TL;DR - the game is a great concept, but it lacks complexity that would make you really immerse with the world. The disconnect between player and NPC is so large, it is actually frustrating. Its not worth your money, honestly.3/10PS: I bought this game back when it was Early Access, but i have played the full release version. My opinion still stands.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Edit: Before I edited this review (See original at the bottom of this review) I took it in a humorous manner, but now, I want to actually speak about the gameplay mechanics and features.     To start out, when you open the game, you  can either play the game or open the map editor (Which is an exceptional addition, but I'll get to that later). Once you have opened the game you get the usual intro of about 3 logos or so, real fast, then you're on to the main menu. Start a new file, pick a prisoner, name that prisoner (optional, default names are provided), then, just like a snap of the fingers, you're in prison for whatever reason. You have one main goal: escape. You have many ways to escape the prison/camp, but each prison/camp varies in difficulty. You can tunnel out most prisons, cut through them, and. if so you wish, take some nunchaku (NunChucks), knock out every guard and just walk out the place.     There is more to the game than meets the eye. Under the nostalgic 16-bit graphics, you have a complicated, yet easily understandable game. There are very many crafting recipes, and yes, I know what you are thinking, "Oh no, another clone trying to rip off the ol' MineCraft crafting mechanic..." But that is not how the crafting works. Sure, you collect items to make something new, but you're not making furnaces or desks, or even beds. You are making your means of escape. After you have made your contraband through the detectors, to your room, or wherever, and make your items, you have to hide them. Cell shakedowns are very common and happen on parameters I'm not sure on yet. Once you have everything you need, its time to move. You have to have impeccable timing skills to escape properly without detection. It took me forever to escape my first prison and that happened only a few days ago. I tried doing it the difficult way, and that only messes you up further. There are relationships between the prisoners (friendship wise), and you need some of them to like you, too. Especially your roommate if you have one.     Let's talk graphics. They're simple, yet elegant, and you can tell what the group of pixels are supposed to be. That is how you do 16-Bit graphics, my PC Master Racers.     I whole-heartedly recommend this game. Now, on to the original review!"I vote this game 10/10. I beat up a guy and took his job, then knocked out a guard with chocolate. If you don't have this game, ask yourself this question: "What am I doing with my life?""

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												this is a hardcore strategy game with a limit of options avalible to you. the amount of options you have depends on which prision you are currently trying to escape from.  Tougher the security is in the prison, less options you'll have. The world is comedic, but you hardly see anything comedic, you only read them through text bubbles. The learning curve is abit steep, but the community has your back there, just check out the Guides in the Guide section on steam for any information you need.  the Ui design is abit " right in your face " and way too large. Everything you have can be taken from you upon death but you can also lose items if you have them. But that depends on if it's " contraband " or not. The maps sizes vary, but most of the maps have a huge ground to cover. The graphics help hide the real brutality which occurs alot in this game, like seeing 3 prisioners fight one another with 5 gaurds jumping into the brawl with nothing but batons. The "death" mechanic is treated more like "knocked out" in the game. But, getting shot by a sniper from a gaurd tower....kinda ruins the supension of disbelief even though the game wants you to think your just knocked out. Annd...well, that's it. That's all I can say on this.The game itself isn't much really. But, it's sure entertaining when you have a need to do a "escape" of sort. Ohh, and my creditials are as follows: I cleared the tutorial, Center Perks, and Stalag Flucht during early access.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overview:This being my first game to purchase on steam, I would say it was a very good investment. The Escapists has given me countless ours of fun and enjoyment. From beating up guards to smuggling contraband around the prison, I've really had a blast with this game and hopefully I can convince you that it is too.  :)First Impressions:I found out about this game by a youtuber called Paulsoares Jr. who sometimes tries out new games on steam. It seemed like a great game; he had lots of fun with it and gave lots of tips and ultimately showed me how to play before I purchased it. I had never seen anything quite like this pixelized prison game, so I decided to scrape up the *ten bucks and give it a go. *The game price has risen a bitHow do I play?:When playing The Escapists, I was helped very much by the in-game tips and by pressing F1, I could see all of the controls; although, it would be helpful if it would have told me more about things like: opinion and how to earn it; and beating up guards and prisoners.Pros:-only $10.00, very worth it *shortly after I bought it, the price rose, but it is still very worth it in my opinion*-tons of crafting items-many different ways to escapeCons:-the game is early access so the game is uncomplete and there are some bugs-no multiplayer-sometimes pretty unbalanced in that if you get caught, all of your hard work goes away :(Summary:I would over all rate this game an 8.5 and I hope you give it a go as I did, I promise you won't regret it!
